baseline_groups.claim_summary: Black-owned businesses pay higher interest rates on small business loans compared to White-owned businesses, controlling for firm, loan, and lender characteristics.
baseline_groups.notes: Primary result: treatment=black_50, outcome=loanrate_w2. Coefficient ~2.9 pp, p=0.002, N=1366, state+time FE, clustered at state level.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Hispanic-owned businesses pay higher interest rates on small business loans compared to White-owned businesses.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline row with treatment_var=hisp_50. Coefficient ~2.93 pp, p=0.008, N=1550.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Asian-owned businesses pay higher interest rates on small business loans compared to White-owned businesses.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline row with treatment_var=asian_50. Coefficient ~2.56 pp, p=0.009, N=1253.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Native American-owned businesses pay higher interest rates on small business loans compared to White-owned businesses.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline row with treatment_var=native_50. Coefficient ~1.30 pp, p=0.26, N=1324. Not statistically significant.

global_notes: The paper studies racial discrimination across four minority groups but the primary focus is on Black-owned businesses (G1). Most robustness specifications (54 of 60) use black_50 as the treatment variable. The baseline spec_id is shared across all four groups (all labeled baseline). Three specs labeled robust/treatment/* re-run the baseline for hisp_50, asian_50, and native_50 and are effectively duplicates of the G2/G3/G4 baselines with slightly different N. One spec (robust/outcome/collval_num) has a missing p-value and near-zero coefficient, flagged as invalid. Placebo tests use predetermined outcomes (term, busage, ceoexp) and are clearly non-core.
